view.name: Municipal Election Candidates
view.description: Official list of candidates for City of Winnipeg Municipal Elections.

cachedContents.largest: With a Bachelor of Interior Design from the Faculty of Architecture Leela could not have anticipated the journey that lead to her running for School Trustee of the St-James- Assiniboia School Division - East Ward.  Some may say this path "found her". Many experiences in her past, including opening and managing medical clinics in South Africa, and volunteering for the board of directors at a large and prominent daycare in Manitoba, have provided the skillset necessary for Leela to navigate this trusteeship with passion and purpose.

top.item: About Cindy, Cindy is a passionate advocate for educational excellence at every age and stage.Since 2018, Cindy has worked tirelessly to generate new channels of communication for families in Ward 3. She continues to be a Trustee of action who is approachable, visible, and creative in engaging community. She ensures the needs of the community are heard at the Board table.Cindy is dedicated to ensuring that students' needs are met socially, emotionally as well as academically.  She supports initiatives that help students thrive and feel confident in their next step.She is a devoted mom of three children who attended K-12 in our division.For 22 years Cindy has worked for the Fort Garry/St. Norbert Healthy Child Coalition facilitating free programs and providing resources for families. She is an experienced community partner with vital services and organizations in the area.A Message from CindyI know the people in my community from a grassroots level, how we've grown and understand the challenges we face. It would be an honour to continue to represent you as a Trustee in Pembina Trails Ward 3.For the love of a child, I will be there!

Amalia Slobogian (BA, MA, B.Ed.) has been involved in education as a graduate student and educator for more than fifteen years. Originally from Winnipeg, she has lived and worked across Canada, teaching middle and high school as well as undergraduates in Quebec, Ontario, and Nunavut. Now a parent of two school-aged children, she is more committed than ever to supporting student learning at all levels. After years of working with students from diverse backgrounds, she is also keenly invested in education that is affordable and socioeconomically equitable so that all children in our community can have positive opportunities and outcomes. Having taught in northern Canada for six years and with one child in the Ukrainian English program, she is especially passionate about matters relating to newcomer, indigenous, and early childhood education. Amalia is currently self-employed as a small business owner and works in the publishing industry. She looks forward to engaging with students, parents, and community members and gaining their input on the challenges facing the schools in our neighbourhood! Please feel free to contact her with any questions or suggestions.

A mother of 3 children attending schools in the St. James School Division, Angela is committed to bringing attention to the issues that most impact children and families: from childcare struggles, bullying, to mental health concerns, etc. As a program coordinator for at-risk families, Angela has experience advocating for the needs of others and ensuring their voices are heard. Angela will use this experience to listen to the St. James community and bring those concerns to the table.  With twelve years experience working alongside children, youth and families; including working as an Educational Assistant. Currently Angela serves children and youth in the child welfare system, and understands the impact caring and committed adults can have in the lives of young people.  Angela has a Bachelor of Arts degree and is working towards achieving her Master's. Angela also has 5 years experience working on boards, including presently serving on the Linwood School Parent Council. It is my sincere hope that St. James-Assiniboia schools can become a haven for all children and youth; driving families of all backgrounds towards bright futures.

Angela Anderson Johnson: I have been a resident in ward 5 for over 7 years. I am a mother to two children attending school in our community, and stepmother to one attending university. I am selfless and devoted to helping people. I am an entrepreneur and business owner through most of my life, serving neighbors and businesses alike.  I have continued to build strong community connections through volunteer initiatives helping the unhoused communities with food and supplies, dedicating my time for various charities, and advocating for all children's rights in our school system.  I might be a fresh face, but I have something to offer. I promise I will work tirelessly to have your voices heard. I will represent each of you and advocate for your needs in our school division. I will review safe transport for our children to get to and from school. I will make sure that all children are treated equally and equitably no matter their situation. My job as your school trustee is to bring the best policies forward. In me you have a partner that will do just that. Our children need our support, and our school boards need people like us, representing the community we live in. The faces you see on the street everyday. We need change in our systems. We need new ideas. We need accountability.

Arlene, and her husband Chris have been residents of Glenelm/Elmwood for the past 15 years. Together they have 3 beautiful boys who all attend schools in the Winnipeg School Division, two at Elmwood High School and one at Glenelm Elementary. She believes in being active in the community and has practical experience with the education system, including the following roles:School Trustee Winnipeg School Division Ward 7 since 2016.Manitoba Association of Parent Councils (2016-present currently serves as President).Program Coordinator/Facilitator for Tots In Elmwood Chalmers Neighbourhood Renewal Corporation Early Years Programming Former Chairperson for the Parent Child Coalition Together in ElmwoodFormer Chairperson and Events Coordinator for Autism Winnipeg PACE. Former Chairperson, Secretary and Treasurer for the Glenelm Parent Advisory Council.In addition to her current role of School Trustee for Ward 7 in WSD, she also works in her community. Since works as a Barista for Starbucks Coffee at the Henderson Hwy location, is the Program Coordinator/Facilitator for Tots in Elmwood (TIE) CNRC Early Years Programming.In her spare time, Arlene also likes to bake cakes and cookies (close to 1600 since she began in 2006).For more information about Arlene visit her website at www.arlenereid.ca

As a mother and North End resident for 24 years, Laurie is passionate about her community and advocating for families. She believes schools have a crucial role to play in providing a safe space and essential supports for children, especially those who are most vulnerable. As the School Trustee for Ward 8, she will ensure WSD students and families have a voice at the school board level.For eight years Laurie worked as the Director of Development for Inner City Youth Alive, an organization that provides a safe, active and nurturing environment for children and youth, many of whom experience poverty, abuse and neglect. She has served on the parent council as Chair at Victoria-Albert School and currently serves on the parent council at St. John's High School, where her son is a student. Laurie has been a member of the board for the North Point Douglas Women's Centre and has worked as an event coordinator for the Multiple Sclerosis Society of Manitoba.Laurie is determined to be part of the change that is needed at the Winnipeg School Division.  She believes in creating a transparent, accountable school board that takes a student-first approach.

As a mother of 2 in the public school system, and an Educational Assistant, Brenda understands the challenges and issues facing both schools and families. She sees students are facing learning loss resulting from COVID-19 restrictions and require increased mental health services. She knows parents need support programs such as before and after school care, lunch programs and bus transportation to be available and affordable when their children need them. Working with Deaf and Hard of Hearing students, Brenda has first-hand knowledge and is keenly aware of the benefits of inclusive education and will ensure that our schools are prepared to guide all our children to excellence in every aspect of their educational journey. As an experienced member on several boards, such as Nursery School, Day Care and Parent Council, Brenda knows the importance of teamwork and collaboration when working towards a common goal. She will be a trustee who is approachable, and available to meet, discuss and address the concerns of parents, staff, and the community.

As a parent, teacher, and special educator, Ann Evangelista is passionate about making sure all students get the best education, support, and resources possible. She believes in creating a strong school board that listens to the concerns of students, families, teachers, workers, educators, and staff. With over 25 years of experience in the education sector (both in Canada and overseas), Ann knows what it takes to create real change. A certified Canada TESL instructor at the University of Winnipeg, she also holds a Master's degree in education and BA (Hons) degree in Psychology and Developmental Studies. She serves on the Board of MAFTI (Manitoba Association of Filipino Teachers), and as the Board Secretary of the UPAA-MB (University of the Philippines Alumni and Associates in Manitoba). She is also the lead advocate for WINCOM (Winnipeg Consular Movement), the call to have a Philippine Consulate Office in Manitoba. Ann also served as a Board Member of Steps2Work, an organization that helps individuals with employment barriers to obtain and maintain employment. Ann envisions a positive culture of leadership by engaging the community and bringing the priorities of Ward 9 to the School Board.

Betty was first elected to the school board in 2018.  She served two terms as Chair of the Winnipeg School Division's Board of Trustees in 2020/21 and 2021/22.  In her role as Chair, Betty provided leadership on the Board of Trustees to save elected school boards from being eliminated by the provincial government's Bill 64.  Betty has lived in the North End on Alfred Ave. for the past 38 years.  She has worked all her life in the North End, including as Director of Housing Supports, End Homelessness Winnipeg; Program Manager, Ma Mawi Wi Chi Itata Centre; Executive Director of Mount Carmel Clinic; Co-Director, Community Education Development Association; and Community Development Worker, Hope Centre Health Care. Betty knows from personal experience that education has the power to change your life.

Born and raised in a working-class home in Steinbach MB, Natalie Smith moved to Winnipeg to complete her BA in Political Science at the University of Winnipeg. She made her home in St. John's with her wife, their rescue dog, and two black cats. Natalie's drive to work for the community started in 2013 when she campaigned for the UPASS referendum for Winnipeg Based Universities, which was passed in 2014. She developed a passion for community services, and has worked in non-profits including Women's Health Clinic and the North End Community Renewal Corp. A musician, Natalie is also on the board for We Rock Winnipeg, a local non-profit that provides opportunities for girls and gender diverse youth to find empowerment through music. Today, Natalie works for Blueprint Inc., a consulting firm that provides strategic planning, training, and guidance on stakeholder relations to municipalities and non-profits. Natalie's campaign is built on the age-old North Winnipeg spirit of people over profit. Her platform addresses community safety, Winnipeg's housing crisis, transit and cycling infrastructure, and more.

Born and raised in Flin Flon, MB I was able to enjoy the outdoors during my time in the public school system.  I moved to Winnipeg at age 17 to attend the University of Manitoba.  I received a BA in Political Studies in 2009.  I have lived in the Westwood neighbourhood since 2015.  Two of my three children currently attend Ecole Robert Browning and the third will start kindergarten fall 2023.  Last year, I was the Vice-President of the ERB Parent Council and will continue to be heavily involved in the school community.  Iâ€™ve been employed with the Canada Border Services Agency for over 12 years in various locations in the Prairies.  I am running for trustee because I believe that there needs to be more parents on the school board that actually have children currently enrolled in the division.  I also believe the current school board suffers from a lack of political balance.  Rigorous and healthy debate are essential to making decisions that affect the lives of our children.  I oppose wasteful spending and believe public education should stick to the fundamentals.  I enjoy speaking with all sorts of people, hearing their personal stories and always offer assistance if I am able to help.

Born and raised in Saint-Boniface, I am thrilled to be running for School Trustee for Louis Riel School Division Ward 1. As the mother of a university student who has been through homeschooling and public schooling, I am confident that I would bring knowledge and wisdom to the table. My work as a professional Translator (business owner for the past 21 years) and French Teacher for the Universite de Saint-Boniface would allow me to exercise my duties in both official languages. As a School Trustee, I am committed to upholding integrity, respect, compassion and positive change. I believe that the voices of parents and students alike should be heard in order to create an effective learning environment.

Born and Raised in Winnipeg, MB all his life, 30 and an only child raised by a single parent. One thing he wants to do on his bucket list in life is to travel across Canada. He is a "Civic Practitioner" and a "Policy Entrepreneur" who has an ambitious vision to run for the office of the mayor in 2014, 2018, 2022, 2026 and 2030.He is no slouch in civic elections. He ran for school trustee in 7 Oaks School Division for ward 2 in 2014. In 2018, he also ran for mayor. On May 1st, 2022 he officially registered his campaign. His 4 key topics of engagement for citizens of Winnipeg are regional coordination, system change, civic innovation, and reasonable government.Since October 11, 2012 almost 10 years and going has been working in a grocery store in the Maples, where he lives. Over the years a colleague and he started an organization called Intercivics. Which is a citizen based group that educates on civics.He participated in the Next Up Leadership program in 2015-2016 which is a national leadership program for young leaders ages 18-32 who are committed to social, economic and environmental justice.

Born in St. Claude, MB, 1971 Graduate of Arthur Meighen H.S. and Institut Collegial St. ClaudeFather of Daniel(Michelle), Stephanie(Dave) and Georges (Ashleigh), grandfather of 6 grandchildren (my joie de vivre) Bilingual resident of St. Boniface for 45 years;  Contractor for 40+ years and 31 years as a Realtor, Extensive experience in data entry, accounting and tax prepCo-Founded St. Boniface Children's Place d'Enfants daycare and served on it's board of directors for many yearsServed as a member of the Board of Directors of Notre Dame Recreation Center for many years. Managed and/or coached hockey teams for about 10 yearsPass times include hunting and fishing, coin collecting and doing genealogyMember of the Knights of Columbus since 2000

Born in St. John's, Newfoundland & Labrador, Gus Watanabe has lived in Whitbourne, NL, Kenora, Thunder Bay and London, ON, Fukui, Japan and Winnipeg for the last 20 years.He's currently a high school guidance counsellor serving at the intersection of the justice, social services, medical (including psychiatric) and education systems.He's focused on applying his experience and knowledge towards producing real world change.He's a graduate of The University of Western Ontario, Lakehead University and The University of Manitoba. He's taught Grades 6-12 in PE, math, ELA, history and geography.He's running for trustee in SJASD's West Ward to promote democratic transparency and accountability in governance and decision making.

Brianne lives with her husband Jesse and their young son Jackson in Ward 3. As a mother, she is committed to continuing to build a stronger education system that will better prepare the next generation. She is a committed education advocate who has brought a fresh vision to the board table. Over the last six years, Brianne has a proven track record of ensuring fiscal accountability, while at the same time prioritizing the needs of children, teachers, and staff in the division. With her professional experience in non-profit advocacy for post-secondary education and public health care, coupled with her current experience in communications; Brianne understands the importance of strong public education for our students. She is dedicated to continuing to serve the community with integrity, honesty, and respect. Brianne currently serves on the boards for Child Care Now, the Child Care Coalition of Manitoba and as the Vice-Chair on the Steering Committee for the Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives-Manitoba. A graduate of both Brock University and the University of Manitoba, Brianne holds an Honours Bachelor of Arts in Sociology with a concentration in Criminology, and a Master of Arts in Sociology.

Craig is a Chartered Professional Accountant (FCPA, FCMA) and worked his entire career as Secretary-Treasurer of Pembina Trails and one of its predecessor school divisions, Fort Garry School Division. This career spanned more than 43 years as Board Secretary and Chief FinancialOfficer. Responsibilities included management of the Division's financial operations, business administration, Board Secretary, collective bargaining, Freedom of Information (FIPPA), records management, transportation and other areas. He worked closely with the Board of Trustees, other Senior Administrators and staff and interacted with the public.All students need to be provided the best possible educational programming and services that meet their needs. The work of the Board of Trustees includes not only ensuring the educational success of our students but exercising proper stewardship of the Division's finances, focusing resources to benefit students effectively, supporting staff in their work and meeting our legal, administrative and oversight obligations as a school division.I believe that my qualifications and extensive experience can make a positive contribution to the work of the Board of Trustees of Pembina Trails School Division.I would appreciate your vote on October 26, 2022.

Craig is committed to ensuring that the current and future generations of the St. James-Assiniboia School Division have access to safe and quality education. It should be designed to not only nurture and care for them, but to guide and fulfill their highest potential. Craig's strong passion of education has lead him to attain his Masters of Business administration from Chaminade University of Honolulu, a Bachelor of Arts (Advanced) from the University of Manitoba, Certificate in Marketing Strategy from Cornell University and a Certificate in Mental Health Leadership from Queen's University.On the St. James - Assiniboina School Division Board, Craig serves as the Chair of the Finance and Facilities committee, overseeing the school divisions budget and audit process, as well ensuring that our divisional facilities are safe and well maintained. In his three years as Chair of the Committee, he was was instrumental in lowering administrative costs and ensuring that hard earned tax dollars are spent in the classroom, on students, where they belong. He has also served as a member of the Community Engagement, and Retirement Committee.He currently works in Corporate Finance and has also served on the Board of Directors at several community based non-profits and associations.

Dante Aviso has lived in West End for more than 20 years and a product of public education where he finished his Grade 12 education at Daniel McIntyre Collegiate Institute and his Business Administration Diploma at Red River College.  Dante believes that public education plays an important role in children's learning and societal development. Maximising student's potential and be an effective voice in the community is his priority. He has served in the community as a leader and volunteer including:-Chairperson, North Valour Residents Association Inc.(NVRA), -Board Member, LiteracyWorks, -Volunteer Teacher's Assistant, Winnipeg School Division 1, -Board Member & Treasurer, Philippine Canadian Centre of Manitoba Inc. (PCCM),-Regional Director, World Championship of Performing Arts (WCOPA),-Volunteer Commissioner for Oaths, Province of Manitoba,-Community volunteers for various Non Profit Organizations, His experience, knowledge and dedication will be a great asset in the School Board. Your Voice, Your Vote!

Darlene Gerrior has lived and worked in the LRSD area since 1972. She is a graduate of Pierre Radisson Collegiate and holds a Master of Education Degree from the University of Manitoba. In her 40 years of Education she has worked in roles from teacher to counsellor, Student Services Coordinator to University Instructor. She is skilled facilitator who delivers workshops to educators and community members. Darlene has worked in our community as a Central Poll Supervisor for the Federal Election and as a returning officer Provincially.She is a Registered Marriage Comissioner, certified mediator, Member of The Council for Exceptional Children with Behavioral Disorders, Board member of IPAM-Indigenous Peoples Alliance of Manitoba. She sits on the WRHA Patient Advisory Council, and is a public Representative on the Inquiry Committee College of Physiotherapists of Manitoba.Darlene is committed to open dialogue and fiscal responsibility. She looks forward to hearing your contents and bringing your voice to the table as your School Trustee LRSD ward 3.

Your Voice, Your Vote!

Jas lives in Seven Oaks since last 13 years with her husband and 10 years old son. Her son goes to a school in the division. She believes in active participation of parents while developing policies & programs for the school division.She is a strong advocate for behavioral development & mental health of children in the schools. Jas envisions teaching social skills and emotional control as an integral part of education system.Jas has Bachelor of Science, Bachelor of Education (B Ed), Master of Science (Entomology) and PG Diploma in journalism. She is a public employee with City of Winnipeg since 2010. She has also mentored few MET school and UofM co-op students.She has volunteered in children's personality development programs with Bulla Arts International. She was involved in raising over $10K for Seven Oaks Performing Arts Centre & over $50K for Baba Nanak Scholarship for Human Rights Program (UofM).She is working hard for new immigrants and has published a Settlement guide for new immigrants (in 2013 & 2017). She also served as Editor of an ethnic community newsmagazine (2011-2020). She looks forward to further serving the community & bringing a positive change in Seven Oaks.

Dr. Marilyn Simon has worked in education for the last twenty-five years. She has done everything from teaching waterskiing at a summer camp as a teenager to teaching upper year Shakespeare courses at the university level. She has taught almost every level of education, from preschool through to middle school and senior high to upper year university courses. For nine years Dr. Marilyn Simon volunteered on the board of a large early education daycare centre that is partnered with the Winnipeg School Division. While there, she served as treasurer. She has taught middle school and holds a Manitoba Teacher's Certificate. She has taught at all three of Winnipeg's major universities. Her breadth of experience with is education is vast, and as a parent as well as an educator, she has seen every level of schooling from the inside and the outside. She has two girls who currently attend schools in the Winnipeg School Division. Dr. Marilyn Simon holds a PhD, a Master of Arts, a Bachelor of Education, and a BA. She is dedicated to teaching and, more importantly, to helping students learn.

I am Greg McFarlane, one of your Seven Oaks School Trustee's, and I am seeking re-election.I am a passionate labour and community leader. With my roots in trades, and as an immigrant to Canada I know the importance of having a voice on the issues that affect us all.I am a proud father of two young children and the only Trustee with children in our division. Along with my life skills, experience and education, having children in our schools emphasizes my vested interest to provide our students with the best possible opportunities. I have helped the division implement programs and initiatives that have had a direct and positive impact on all students and their future. I believe teaching our students the skills necessary to succeed, whether through university or pursing alternative career paths is paramount. As Chair of the Board last term, we faced new and deeply challenging circumstances notably Bill 64 and the pandemic. Through these challenges we were able to pivot and adjust while still achieving high education outcomes and keep what we hold dear in Seven Oaks. With your support, I hope to continue serving the community progressively.

My name is Liz Jackimec and I am running for school trustee in Ward 5 because I am passionate about giving our children the best education possible. I am a graduate of Tec-Voc High School and I have two children who have attended Ward 5 schools. My oldest has graduated and my younger one is in Grade 11. In my 20 years of living in this ward I have been involved with parent councils at the elementary, middle years and high school levels, and have sat as Chairperson on two of them. I work and volunteer at the Valour Community Centre where I am President of the volunteer board. I am also on the Board of the South Valour Residents Association. Being this involved with my community and local schools has fostered a belief that to effectively educate our children we need to look at the whole child, not just academic performance. To accomplish this I will advocate for universal meal programs in our schools, more mental health supports, additional extracurricular activities, and more funding for Educational Assistants.If we all work together; families, communities, educators; we can ensure our children receive the high quality education they deserve!

Born in St. Claude, MB, 1971 Graduate of Arthur Meighen H.S. and Institut Collegial St. ClaudeFather of Daniel(Michelle), Stephanie(Dave) and Georges (Ashleigh), grandfather of 6 grandchildren (my joie de vivre) Bilingual resident of St. Boniface for 45 years;  Contractor for 40+ years and 31 years as a Realtor, Extensive experience in data entry, accounting and tax prepCo-Founded St. Boniface Children's Place d'Enfants daycare and served on it's board of directors for many yearsServed as a member of the Board of Directors of Notre Dame Recreation Center for many years. Managed and/or coached hockey teams for about 10 yearsPass times include hunting and fishing, coin collecting and doing genealogyMember of the Knights of Columbus since 2000

Tamara (she/her) lives in Ward 7 in the Luxton neighbourhood with her husband Marc and their two children Ruth and Jack. She grew up in the ward and attended Luxton School from kindergarten to grade 6. She values the connection to local, public, community schools and is thrilled that her kids could attend Luxton as well.    Tamara has served as both Secretary and Chair of the Ecole Luxton School Parent Advisory Committee (PAC) in recent years. She was a vocal opponent of Bill 64 and helped organize efforts to successfully stop its attempt to limit local voice in education. Throughout the pandemic, she has been an advocate for safe school spaces for staff and students.   Tamara spent nearly two decades working for MTS and worked her way up from managing payphones to running strategic planning through the presidents' office, then leading divisions through transformational projects. As the sale of MTS to Bell became imminent, she decided it was time to align her work more closely with her values. Since, she has helped local businesses and industry, governments, and arts-based organizations with public consultation, strategic planning and board governance. Throughout this work, she has focused on ways to help Winnipeg thrive.

Derek Dabee successfully ran for a seat on the Seven Oaks School Board in 2010, when a longtime Trustee was retiring.He saw it only as an opportunity to contribute to the improvement to our valued education system.Derek has served as: . Chair of the Board. Chair of the Policy Committee . Chair of the Budget Committee .  Member of the Equity and Diversity Committee * President of Maples Community Centre - 5 years Derek is very proud to assist in the huge progress in the School Div., including:. Building five new schools and renovating dozens of schools & playgrounds . Lower taxes and safer classrooms. Five new Daycare Centres. Saving parents 70% in school supply costs & no fees field trips.  School gyms are opened for after school activities Derek Dabee; a former instructor, is well known for coaching and volunteering. Recipient - of the City's  Outstanding Volunteer Award.

She believes in creating a transparent, accountable school board that takes a student-first approach.

I was born and raised in St. Vital, here in Ward 2. I attended Hastings and Dakota before going on to graduate from both the University of Winnipeg and the University of Manitoba.My mother taught at Hastings School for many years and my father was a school principal. Today my wife and I live in ward 2 (just 2 blocks from the house I grew up in) and my kids are LRSD students. A lawyer by profession, I grew up with educator parents who surrounded me with talk about and a passion for education. When my own children started school here in LRSD I wanted to use that passion by getting involved in our local school system and was elected as a trustee. Together, our school community has faced many challenges in recent years. We pulled together to defeat Bill 64 so that local people can still have a say in local schools. We weathered the unprecedented challenge of a world-wide pandemic. I'm proud of our community and our division for facing these challenges head on. Now is the time to keep our focus where it belongs, on better educational outcomes for all our students.

Born in St. John's, Newfoundland & Labrador, Gus Watanabe has lived in Whitbourne, NL, Kenora, Thunder Bay and London, ON, Fukui, Japan and Winnipeg for the last 20 years.He's currently a high school guidance counsellor serving at the intersection of the justice, social services, medical (including psychiatric) and education systems.He's focused on applying his experience and knowledge towards producing real world change.He's a graduate of The University of Western Ontario, Lakehead University and The University of Manitoba. He's taught Grades 6-12 in PE, math, ELA, history and geography.He's running for trustee in SJASD's West Ward to promote democratic transparency and accountability in governance and decision making.

Kathy is a strong advocate for student centred education. Kathy is a high school teacher and passionate about community capacity building.  She possesses degrees in both Education and Human Resource Management in addition to a Master of Inclusive Education.Kathy recognizes the importance of language programs and diversity in education due to her experience with international community development.  She is a co-founder of the WSD Spanish Bilingual program established in 2016 at Earl Grey School, the first of its kind in Manitoba. Her youngest daughter attends the program. The work involved in proposing the program gave Kathy extensive experience working with school boards and administration, the Department of Education, local communities, and the Spanish Embassy.Kathy is the Chair of the Earl Grey Parent Advisory Council and has previously served as Vice-Chair of the Dante Day Nursery Board of Directors where she led policy and board development. Kathy Heppner and her husband Carl have four children who all have or currently attend schools in WSD Ward 3; Earl Grey School, Ecole River Heights School, and Ecole Kelvin High School.

As a mother of 2 in the public school system, and an Educational Assistant, Brenda understands the challenges and issues facing both schools and families. She sees students are facing learning loss resulting from COVID-19 restrictions and require increased mental health services. She knows parents need support programs such as before and after school care, lunch programs and bus transportation to be available and affordable when their children need them. Working with Deaf and Hard of Hearing students, Brenda has first-hand knowledge and is keenly aware of the benefits of inclusive education and will ensure that our schools are prepared to guide all our children to excellence in every aspect of their educational journey. As an experienced member on several boards, such as Nursery School, Day Care and Parent Council, Brenda knows the importance of teamwork and collaboration when working towards a common goal. With 12 years' experience supporting parents, educators, ratepayers and the entire St. James Assiniboia community as one of your Trustees, Sandy Lethbridge is seeking re-election in the West Ward with a renewed commitment to student success and stronger educational outcomes.  With a proven track record as an advocate and representative, Sandy represented St. James Assiniboia with the Manitoba School Boards Association as a Director representing Metropolitan Winnipeg Divisions and currently as one of the two Vice Presidents.  Sandy believes the continual lack of a sustainable, predictable and fully funded public education system is a critical challenge facing school boards and will continue to advocate for greater support for our schools. Every student deserves the opportunity to receive a rich, equitable, and full education that embraces their passions and challenges them to become global citizens.  All schools shall provide a welcoming, safe and inclusive learning environment, so students can attend school free from all forms of bullying, racism, discrimination and harassment.  Sandy continues to support the parent voice in public education. She served 13 years as an active Parent Advisory Council (PAC) Member and 7 years as a Member of the Music Parents Council (MPC).

I am a lifelong resident of St. James and attended Stevenson, George Waters, and St. James Collegiate.The past nine years I have worked as a middle school teacher in Seven Oaks School Division. All in all, I would be honoured and humbled to receive your vote on October 26th

Since I was first elected in 2014, my mission as member of the Louis Riel School Division Board of Trustees has been to be a voice for our community. I am running for School Trustee to be a real true voice for families. I feel there has been a trend of complacency that has settled into boardrooms. It seems there is a "go along to get along" mentality, rather than a family-first mentality. True leadership means common-sense should come first. If it means facing uncomfortable situations, I'm willing to do that.1.	Sex and gender discussion with children. I am not convinced this is healthy or necessary with youngsters. School is supposed to be a safe place where kids can go learn the basics that will help them succeed as they mature. 2.	Recently, the circus in Ontario, has created the need to address dress codes and decorum in the school. No one should be exempt from showing respect, courtesy and basic decorum to their colleagues and peers, regardless of who they are, or what  they identify as. 3.	Raising taxes. I think there are a LOT of areas where school expenses can be trimmed. It seems now, that the default position of trustees is to raise taxes.  We need solutions that are creative and intelligent...instead of reaching into family pocketbooks.

Janice is seeking a third Council term to serve the residents of the Waverley West ward, to represent their interests at City Hall and to work with a Mayor and Council to improve the quality of life for all residents of Winnipeg.Janice has a proven track record of delivering results for the residents of the Waverley West ward and all Winnipeggers. She's worked with levels of government to secure $100 million for a new recreation campus, and $15 million for a new fire station in the Waverley West ward. She has championed the battle against illegal rooming houses, and worked with city builders to enable development of over 4,000 safe apartment and condo units in south Winnipeg. And for almost two decades, Janice has raised millions, and taken a lead role in improving walking and cycling throughout Winnipeg. She is a problem solver with a 'can do' approach, and chisels through red tape and bureaucracy to improve systems and processes. As a 'grass roots' organizer, she is actively engaged on social media platforms and is constantly communicating local issues and opportunities to residents and seeking feedback.  Long before being elected to Council, Janice was involved in her community and has been recognized for her commitment with the following acknowledgements:- Queen Elizabeth II Golden Jubilee Award- President's Council Award Manitoba School Board Association- Province of Manitoba - Premiere's Volunteer Service Award- YWCA Women of Distinction Award- Active and Safe Routes to School - School Champion Award- Winnipeg Trails Association Coordinator - Long Service AwardShe and her husband are the proud parents of triplet boys, and are caregivers to a rescue Norwegian Elk Hound doggie, a rescue fat cat and a happily rescued fluffy rabbit. They all live together - as harmoniously as possible!

Born and raised in a working-class home in Steinbach MB, Natalie Smith moved to Winnipeg to complete her BA in Political Science at the University of Winnipeg. She made her home in St. John's with her wife, their rescue dog, and two black cats. Natalie's drive to work for the community started in 2013 when she campaigned for the UPASS referendum for Winnipeg Based Universities, which was passed in 2014. She developed a passion for community services, and has worked in non-profits including Women's Health Clinic and the North End Community Renewal Corp. A musician, Natalie is also on the board for We Rock Winnipeg, a local non-profit that provides opportunities for girls and gender diverse youth to find empowerment through music. Today, Natalie works for Blueprint Inc., a consulting firm that provides strategic planning, training, and guidance on stakeholder relations to municipalities and non-profits. Natalie's campaign is built on the age-old North Winnipeg spirit of people over profit. Her platform addresses community safety, Winnipeg's housing crisis, transit and cycling infrastructure, and more.

Linda is a parent and foster care provider who has lived in the Garden Grove school community for over 30 years.  Linda is a proud Metis with roots that originate from St. Laurent, Manitoba. She is also a member of the Manitoba Metis Federation and serves as chair for the Metis Elder and Youth Local. As a foster care provider, Linda has gained experience in navigating the Child and Family Services system. She is known as a strong advocate for children in care and within the school system.  Linda has been active in the school community for many years. Linda and her husband Doug have been together for more than 30 years, she has two adult sons and a daughter in law and four grandchildren.  She is known by others to be caring and willing to support those in need. She always makes the time to meet with people to hear their ideas or concerns and works with them to find a solution.  She believes that with all the diversity in our city, communication is a priority within our school and community. Linda believes that children must come first, as they are the future.

Linda loves children!  She has three of her own and is expecting her first grandchild soon.  She believes that every child should have the opportunity for a superior education graduating from high school with excellent basic skills (reading, writing, mathematics), great character skills that will serve them for a lifetime, top-notch preparation for the workforce or post secondary and be a critical thinker.  She believes in good stewardship of tax dollars focussing money into teacher and classroom support.  Common sense budgetary and policy decisions are of prime importance.  Parental involvement in education should be supported and encouraged.

Ryan Kochie is a father of four and has worked for nearly 20 years in the culinary industry, often in a leadership and supervisory role becoming a red seal chef. He helps to run various online support groups including founding the long standing Parents of Winnipeg (POWSA Village), a successful resource for Parents across the city to connect on-line and in person. He also administers the marketplace Buy/Sell Winnipeg to help small local businesses advertise their wares and services and give access to people to easily sell their used items to the community. He will apply those same leadership, communication, organizational, and management skills in city hall and our community to make our area safer, more active, and more engaged. His intent is to be able to actively listen and communicate to many of you on what your priorities are, being available and responding in a timely manner to the concerns of local residents. He will bring that same passion he brings for all his endeavours to council.

Jasmine Brar is honoured to be your School Trustee candidate in Pembina Trails Ward 3. Jasmine is a lifelong resident of Winnipeg, having graduated from Oak Park High School and resides in ward 3, with her husband, two children and family dog Teddy. Jasmine is currently the Department Manager with the University of Manitoba and is an active volunteer in our community. She is the founder and president of the Prairie Pointe Neighborhood Association and serves as Vice President at the South Winnipeg Community Centre. She was a member of the South Winnipeg Action Team, which played an integral part to secure funding for recreational facilities within our community and bring attention to the concerns of parents such as catchment areas for neighborhood schools. As a mother and a grass roots community volunteer, Jasmine is passionate about children and the neighborhoods we live in. Ensuring children and their parents having access to innovative and progressive resources that allow for a fulfilling educational experience, is a driving force behind Jasmine joining this race. With changing demographics and new Canadians joining our schools annually, it is important to have a voice that understands them, Jasmine herself is an immigrant who moved to Winnipeg with her family 25 years ago.

Patrick Allard has lived in ward 8 for 41 years.Lifelong resident, part of three generations of Winnipeg school division students.A north end business owner who values the neighborhood he calls home.He knows what the community needs and will fight to have the best schooling experience possible for students.Patrick will ensure that parents and families have easier access to board members to voice their opinions and concerns.Patrick Allard, as trustee will make sure that board meetings are open and more accessible to all so that you may attend and have your voice heard.Patrick understands that parents are first in their children's lives and the school board should listen and address the needs of a student's parents and families.He is passionate about keeping schooling first when it comes to how your child's education is applied. Reading, writing and arithmetic are basic schooling principles that will be once again be priorities through Patrick.As a long time business owner he understands how to budget and negotiate better spending power for your hard earned tax dollars.With your vote and trust, Patrick Allard, a lifelong community member can help bring your voice to the forefront.

Born and raised in Saint-Boniface, I am thrilled to be running for School Trustee for Louis Riel School Division Ward 1. As the mother of a university student who has been through homeschooling and public schooling, I am confident that I would bring knowledge and wisdom to the table. My work as a professional Translator (business owner for the past 21 years) and French Teacher for the Universite de Saint-Boniface would allow me to exercise my duties in both official languages. As a School Trustee, I am committed to upholding integrity, respect, compassion and positive change. I believe that the voices of parents and students alike should be heard in order to create an effective learning environment.

I am past-Chair of the Louis Riel School Board, Chair of the Louis Riel Endowment Fund Committee, a member of the Manitoba School Boards Association executive, serve on the board of directors of Dakota Community Centre, contribute a regular column to the Community Review East, and am an employee of the University of Manitoba. My approach and promise to the LRSD community, since first elected in 2010, has been this: school trustees must understand elected governance, remain visible and engaged in their community, stay informed on current and emerging issues, and demonstrate commitment to the work and effectiveness in the role. I will continue to support: investments in full-day kindergarten, mental health wellness for students and staff, and our Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Anti-Racism Initiative; the use of data to inform conversations, decisions, directions, and the monitoring of progress; concerted efforts to reduce the achievement gap between Indigenous and non-Indigenous students; endeavors with a goal of mitigating the impact of poverty on student engagement and success; advocacy efforts directed at government for funding that is adequate and sustainable; transparency and accountability in decision making; and opportunities for engagement with students, families, staff and public.

With a Bachelor of Interior Design from the Faculty of Architecture Leela could not have anticipated the journey that lead to her running for School Trustee of the St-James- Assiniboia School Division - East Ward.  Some may say this path "found her". Many experiences in her past, including opening and managing medical clinics in South Africa, and volunteering for the board of directors at a large and prominent daycare in Manitoba, have provided the skillset necessary for Leela to navigate this trusteeship with passion and purpose.

I am running for Pembina Trails School Division, Ward 1, School Board Trustee. I retired from teaching at Oak Park High School and volunteering in the Charleswood community for the past 20 years. The current school board has established an exceptionally talented senior administrative team. I have been fortunate to work directly with a few of these leaders. I look forward to working with them in the upcoming term.

Matthew has grown up in the school division attending school in Transcona and afterwards moving with his family to live in Ward 3. As a young adult, Matthew has been committed to engaging in transformative ways with both conflict and community development. This includes taking the time to listen to the experiences and concerns of various parties and bringing their thoughts and ideas to the table. Matthew's goal in being a school trustee is to become an advocate for the teachers, staff, and students of the River East Transcona School Division, giving a place for their ideas to be shared and heard in a meaningful way while also continuously advocating for the importance of school programs such as the arts and outdoor education. Matthew holds a Bachelor of Arts from Canadian Mennonite University with a major in Peace and Conflict Transformation Studies and minors in Sociology and Biblical Theological Studies and is currently pursuing a Masters in Peace and Justice Studies through St. Stephen's University. Matthew is also a current board member of ASJ (Association For a More Just Society) Canada and is currently slated to be a Canadian delegate at the 2023 Peace Summit For Emerging Leaders in Bangkok, Thailand.

Robert Page, a retired high school teacher, followed by years of substitute teaching, has worked in education for years. Robert's goal is to contribute to the profession from which he and his family have benefitted.After serving a term as a trustee in Seine River School Division, Robert became a trustee in LRSD in 2016. Experience counts. "Having subbed in Louis Riel School Division, and having had children enrolled in classes here, I am proud of the quality of teaching that I have witnessed and that they received," Robert says. "We also have an energized group of superintendents that keep LRSD a progressive environment in which children learn." Passionate about drama and musical activities, Robert feels both the intellectual and emotional levels of intelligence are enriched as students work effectively with others and engage in writing, reading, speaking, and creativity. Robert supports effective programs in both Canada's official languages. He supports a school division that promotes inclusiveness, a strong work ethic and provides schools staffed with knowledgeable, supportive and caring teachers that work with parents to develop good citizens.

A mother of 3 children attending schools in the St. James School Division, Angela is committed to bringing attention to the issues that most impact children and families: from childcare struggles, bullying, to mental health concerns, etc. As a program coordinator for at-risk families, Angela has experience advocating for the needs of others and ensuring their voices are heard. Angela also has 5 years experience working on boards, including presently serving on the Linwood School Parent Council. It is my sincere hope that St. James-Assiniboia schools can become a haven for all children and youth; driving families of all backgrounds towards bright futures.

It has been an honour to serve as a trustee in Ward 4.  I have brought a new perspective to the Board, advocating for enhanced communications within the community. My nephews attend schools in the area, and it is important that they, and all children succeed in their education.

She looks forward to hearing your contents and bringing your voice to the table as your School Trustee LRSD ward 3.

David was elected to the Pembina Trails School Board in 2002 and re-elected in 2006, 2010, 2014 and 2018.  He has served as both Chair of the Board and Vice-Chair and he has been a member of all of the Board's standing committees as well as numerous ad hoc committees. He currently serves Chair of the Finance, Buildings, Property and Transportation Committee. David and his wife Katherine have lived in Fort Garry for the past 25 years. Their sons Magnus and Eric are both graduates of Vincent Massey Collegiate.  David grew up in Charleswood. He graduated from Oak Park High School and later from the University of Manitoba.Over the years David has held senior positions in both the public and private sectors. He founded Strata Research, a company specializing in demographic mapping and database marketing.  David's main focus is his family. For many years he has served as a community volunteer and supported his sons' hockey and soccer teams.Pembina Trails is an incredible School Division. David is seeking re-election to the School Board because he wants to ensure that the Division continues to provide quality programming in a safe and caring environment through responsible fiscal management.

Gursharn Wander has a Master of Computer Science and a diploma in Vocational Teacher Education. He has over 17 years of teaching experience and is currently an instructor at the Manitoba Institute of Trades and Technology. He has organized Manitoba Skills Competition over the last eight years in technology and cyber defense. He is the proud father of two school-age daughters and has been living in Ward 2 of Seven Oaks School Division for the last 15 years. He envisions that schools should provide a quality education through an inclusive learning environment that encourages all students to invent the future by developing curiosity, imagination, and resilience. At the same time, he firmly believes that there is a dire need to invest and provide more resources to improve the mental health and social skills of students. He has been an active volunteer for many years supporting various neighborhood initiatives. He volunteered to mentor children in the annual communication skills competition. He actively volunteered to raise over $50K for the Baba Nanak Scholarship for Human Rights Education at the University of Manitoba. He also volunteered to keep the neighborhood safe and participated to create a new community garden in Maples Community.

Todd McDougall has lived in PTSD Ward 2 for 21 years and has family history in the area dating back to the early 1960's.He is a father and worked 13 years in childcare in the area. During this time, he worked alongside a local church, community club and the Pembina Trails School Division. His time working with teachers, principals and other faculty members has given him a lot of insight into the challenges facing our educational system and his time working with parents has shown him the importance of community involvement and transparency. Seeing families struggle to pay for childcare over the years, Todd knows how important it is for families to know that their money is being spent in their best interest. Todd believes the best way to do this is to ensure all meetings are open to the public and promoted publicly as such and to focus primarily on the basics of public education. A strong advocate for community pride and events, Todd would like to see your voice be heard more when it comes to your community and your children's education.

Brianne lives with her husband Jesse and their young son Jackson in Ward 3. As a mother, she is committed to continuing to build a stronger education system that will better prepare the next generation. She is a committed education advocate who has brought a fresh vision to the board table. Over the last six years, Brianne has a proven track record of ensuring fiscal accountability, while at the same time prioritizing the needs of children, teachers, and staff in the division. With her professional experience in non-profit advocacy for post-secondary education and public health care, coupled with her current experience in communications; Brianne understands the importance of strong public education for our students. She is dedicated to continuing to serve the community with integrity, honesty, and respect. Brianne currently serves on the boards for Child Care Now, the Child Care Coalition of Manitoba and as the Vice-Chair on the Steering Committee for the Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives-Manitoba. A graduate of both Brock University and the University of Manitoba, Brianne holds an Honours Bachelor of Arts in Sociology with a concentration in Criminology, and a Master of Arts in Sociology.

Betty was first elected to the school board in 2018.  She served two terms as Chair of the Winnipeg School Division's Board of Trustees in 2020/21 and 2021/22.  In her role as Chair, Betty provided leadership on the Board of Trustees to save elected school boards from being eliminated by the provincial government's Bill 64.  Betty has lived in the North End on Alfred Ave. for the past 38 years.  She has worked all her life in the North End, including as Director of Housing Supports, End Homelessness Winnipeg; Program Manager, Ma Mawi Wi Chi Itata Centre; Executive Director of Mount Carmel Clinic; Co-Director, Community Education Development Association; and Community Development Worker, Hope Centre Health Care. Betty knows from personal experience that education has the power to change your life.

Tim is an active supporter of the Ward 2 communities, a strong advocate for public education, and an experienced school trustee.  His volunteer work has been recognized with awards such as, "Outstanding Citizen's Award for Leadership in the Community" from the City of Winnipeg and the "President's Award for Outstanding Leadership" in the Fort Garry community. Tim believes that an effective trustee is someone who can work with others and has demonstrated, through past and current actions, a genuine regard for improving the services in our community.  In addition, a Trustee must be present, engaged and understand board governance.  "Tim has impressed me with his desire to always think about what is best for students and to support decisions that make sense for families and the broader community. He is approachable, knowledgeable, and a proven leader, all tremendous assets to the role of School Trustee." - Sue Clayton, Lindenwoods Resident.  "I support clean, healthy, and a secure environment in schools and common areas; data informed decisions; respect for the needs and social development of all students; and, programming for engagement and academic success. Let's continue working together by entrusting me with your vote."

Arlene, and her husband Chris have been residents of Glenelm/Elmwood for the past 15 years. Together they have 3 beautiful boys who all attend schools in the Winnipeg School Division, two at Elmwood High School and one at Glenelm Elementary. She believes in being active in the community and has practical experience with the education system, including the following roles:School Trustee Winnipeg School Division Ward 7 since 2016.Manitoba Association of Parent Councils (2016-present currently serves as President).Program Coordinator/Facilitator for Tots In Elmwood Chalmers Neighbourhood Renewal Corporation Early Years Programming Former Chairperson for the Parent Child Coalition Together in ElmwoodFormer Chairperson and Events Coordinator for Autism Winnipeg PACE. Former Chairperson, Secretary and Treasurer for the Glenelm Parent Advisory Council.In addition to her current role of School Trustee for Ward 7 in WSD, she also works in her community. Since works as a Barista for Starbucks Coffee at the Henderson Hwy location, is the Program Coordinator/Facilitator for Tots in Elmwood (TIE) CNRC Early Years Programming.In her spare time, Arlene also likes to bake cakes and cookies (close to 1600 since she began in 2006).For more information about Arlene visit her website at www.arlenereid.ca

My name is Colin Cherpako. I am father of 4 beautiful children and I am deeply humbled to be given the opportunity to run for School Trustee in Ward 5 of the Winnipeg School Division. As a resident of the area I know how unique the challenges are for the children in Ward 5.I graduated Red River College with my Educational Assistant Certificate. I reluctantly left my job as an EA in 2020 to pursue my current career with Winnipeg Transit.  I would now like to return to the school system in the role of School Trustee. Three major things I want to work on as your trustee is Improved/additional Breakfast, Lunch, and afternoon programs to make sure our future leaders have as much opportunity possible.Inclusive, caring, and safe classrooms for all students as well as increased advocacy for students who have disabilities.The third point is by far the most important. I want to make sure you as a resident and voter have a say in our school system. Trustees are elected to represent you and if elected I will make sure I will be open and available to hear your concerns.
Alex Yaworski, CPA, CMA, CMC, Partner
